chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for oral itraconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Avoid oral itraconazole in:
    • People with acute porphyria.
    • Pregnant or breastfeeding women.
  • Avoid oral itraconazole or use with caution in: 
    • People with hepatic impairment, a history of hepatotoxicity with other drugs, or active liver disease. 
      • Liver function tests are not usually necessary for a course of treatment lasting less than 1 month, unless the person is taking concurrent hepatotoxic drugs, has a history of hepatotoxicity, or has hepatic impairment.
      • Advise the person to report signs of liver disease (such as anorexia, nausea and vomiting, fatigue, abdominal pain, or dark urine) and seek prompt medical attention.
  • Use oral itraconazole with caution in:
    • Older adults.
    • People with cardiac disease and those being treated with negative inotropic drugs (such as calcium channel blockers).
    • People with chronic lung disease associated with pulmonary hypertension (including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]).
    • People with HIV infection and neutropenia — absorption of itraconazole is reduced.
    • People with renal impairment — increased risk of heart failure and the bioavailability of oral itraconazole possibly reduced.
    • Women of childbearing age — ensure effective contraception during treatment and until the next menstrual period following end of treatment.

[ABPI, 2018a; BNF, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of oral itraconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adverse effects commonly include: 
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, constipation, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, hypokalaemia, headache, heart failure, oedema, skin reactions, and vision disorders.
  • Rare cases of serious hepatotoxicity have been reported — advise the person to seek medical advice if they experience anorexia, vomiting, fatigue, abdominal pain, or dark urine.

[ABPI, 2018a; BNF, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the drug interactions of oral itraconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Absorption of itraconazole is decreased when gastric acidity is reduced (for example by antacids, H2-receptor antagonists, or proton pump inhibitors).
  • Effect of itraconazole is reduced (due to cytochrome P450 CYP3A4 enzyme induction) by drugs such as carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, rifampicin, and rifabutin — avoid concurrent use.
  • Antipsychotic drugs:
    • Itraconazole is predicted to increase the exposure to pimozide, quetiapine, and sertindole, manufacturer advises avoidance.  
    • Itraconazole increases the concentration of haloperidol and risperidone, manufacturer advises caution/dose adjustment.
  • Antiretroviral drugs — itraconazole increases the levels of most protease inhibitors, and itraconazole levels are increased by ritonavir and possibly indinavir. Manufacturer recommends avoiding concurrent use with nevirapine or efavirenz.
  • Calcium-channel blockers — monitor blood pressure control and heart rate, and for calcium-channel blocker adverse effects, particularly for felodipine. Itraconazole use with lercanidipine or nisoldipine is contraindicated by the manufacturer.
  • Disopyramide, ivabradine, mizolastine, and ranolazine — plasma levels of these drugs are increased by itraconazole, leading to an increased risk of arrhythmias.
  • Digoxin — monitor for signs of digoxin toxicity, and adjust the dose accordingly.
  • Ergotamine and methysergide — avoid concurrent use, owing to the increased risk of ergotism.  
  • Eletriptan — avoid concurrent use. Itraconazole increases eletriptan levels almost three-fold.
  • Eplerenone — itraconazole increases the bioavailability of eplerenone more than five-fold, avoid concurrent use
  • Phosphodiesterase type-5 inhibitors — ketoconazole markedly increases the levels of tadalafil, very markedly increases the levels of vardenafil, and may also increase the levels of sildenafil. Itraconazole is predicted to interact similarly — manufacturer advises use with caution or avoidance.
  • Statins — avoid concurrent use of simvastatin and atorvastatin with itraconazole.  
  • Other interactions include:
    • Warfarin — itraconazole potentially increases the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, monitor the international normalized ratio (INR) closely.  
    • Ciclosporin — increases concentration of ciclosporin, manufacturer advises caution.
    • Reboxetine — the manufacturer advises that itraconazole should not be given with reboxetine.
    • Tacrolimus — monitor tacrolimus levels and adjust dose.

[Baxter, 2013; ABPI, 2018a; BNF, 2020]
